title: Does my co-borrower have to sign the reaffirmation agreement with my lender if he filed for BK in 2010 and I filed December 2013
question: I want to refinance my loan in the future to remove my co-borrower. Do I have to reaffirm the loan to refinance in the future. My goal is to remove the co-borrower.
answers: If the co-borrower obtained a discharge back in 2010, then there is no co-borrower on your loan. Therefore, there is no need for the co-borrower to sign. Also, most attorneys will advise against signing a reaffirmation on real estate. If you want to refinance, seek out another lender now.

Some lenders require a reaffirmation before they will refinance, but you do not have to return to your lender. The best answer you will receive is to call a mortgage broker or a bank and ask their requirements.

Unless you are refinancing with your existing mortgage lender, I don't know how doing so makes any difference. If to sign the reaffirmation agreement and then the loan is refinanced, the reaffirmation agreement accomplishes nothing as it is replaced by the new note.

Your lender may require a reaffirmation agreement but if that's the case you should look for another lender. Even if you sign a reaffirmation agreement, something most attorneys would NEVER advise on a mortgage loan, that does not guarantee you will be able to refinance. Signing a reaffirmation agreement on a mortgage will create personal liability for a debt which would otherwise be discharged in your bankruptcy which may expose you to legal liability in the event of a judicial foreclosure sale down the road. California is a state that allows both judicial and non-judicial foreclosure sales. While the great majority of them are non-judicial foreclosure sales, some lenders do utilize the court system to foreclose.

I also believe most judges in California will deny a reaffirmation agreement for a mortgage loan.

Before you make what could turn out to be a very big mistake, make a consultation with a bankruptcy attorney who can advise you of all the risks and benefits of reaffirming a mortgage.
